choices.text: Cardiac branch from superior cervical ganglion of left sympathetic trunk
Cardiac branch from middle cervical ganglion of right sympathetic trunk
Cardiac branch of right recurrent laryngeal nerve
Lower cervical cardiac branch of right vagus

questions.text: The marked structure in image is a vital component of the autonomic nervous system, regulating cardiac function by influencing heart rate and contraction strength. Dysfunction of this can lead to arrhythmias and other cardiac issues, requiring careful assessment and management in cardiology practice. Which of the following doesn’t contribute to the given plexus?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Cardiac branch from superior cervical ganglion of left sympathetic trunk

choices.text: The left anterior descending artery lies in the anterior interventricular sulcus
It is accompanied by great cardiac vein
It supplies anterior 2/3 of interventricular septum
It anastomoses with the posterior interventricular branch at the apex of the heart

questions.text: A 57-year-old male lorry driver presented to his local emergency department with a 20-minute episode of diaphoresis and chest pain. The chest pain was central, radiating to the left arm and crushing in nature. The pain settled promptly following 300 mg aspirin orally and 800 mcg glyceryl trinitrate (GTN) spray sublingually administered by paramedics in the community. On examination, he appeared comfortable and was able to complete sentences fully. There were no heart murmurs present on cardiac auscultation. Blood pressure was 180/105 mmHg, heart rate was 83 bpm and regular, oxygen saturation was 97%. He was taken to the catheterization lab where the left anterior descending coronary artery (LAD) was shown to be completely occluded. Which of the following statements is incorrect about LAD?
questions.solution: Ans. D) It anastomoses with the posterior interventricular branch at the apex of the heart

choices.text: Stability of the Pelvic Ring is based in Large Part by Ligamentous attachments
The Internal Iliac Artery is known as the “Pelvic Artery”
Chance of Injury to Membranous or Spongy Urethra should be excluded
Internal Iliac Artery forms the Anterior Boundary of Ovarian Fossa in a Female

questions.text: A 33-year-old male presents to the E.R. after a motorcycle accident. The patient is awake and alert, and reports pain in his abdomen and pelvis. On physical examination, the heart rate is 120 bpm, blood pressure is 120/60 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 30 breaths/min. Examination also reveals abrasions on abdominal wall surface and no signs or presence of blood on external urethral meatus. Palpation reveals generalized tenderness over the entire abdominal region. In addition, the patient shows particular discomfort when stability of the pelvis is assessed by placing hands over his pubic symphysis and laterally applying pressure over the iliac blades. He does not have full hip extension and rotation in supine lying. Rectal exam is negative for gross blood, and the patient has a normally placed prostate. X-Rays of the pelvis in 3 planes (AP, lateral, and oblique views) was ordered to determine if the patient has a fractured pelvis and a flat plate of the abdomen to determine if the patient has free air in his abdomen. A diagnostic supraumbilical peritoneal lavage turns out negative. The patient was diagnosed with a pelvic fracture, complicated by internal bleeding. Angiography showed a laceration of the internal pudendal artery, and a selective embolization is performed. External fixation of the pelvis is performed after the bleeding has been stabilized. Which of the following statements pertaining to the above case is not true?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Internal Iliac Artery forms the Anterior Boundary of Ovarian Fossa in a Female

choices.text: Perforated Ulcer on the Posterior Wall of the Stomach can Damage Splenic Artery
The Shoulder Pain was referred Pain due to Irritation of Diaphragm by Gastric Juices
Vagotomy Reduces Acid Secretion of Stomach
Collateral Circulation from Branches of Superior Mesenteric Artery will compensate Occlusion of Left Gastric Artery

questions.text: A 50-year-old business executive was admitted to the hospital after visiting the emergency room complaining of severe epigastric pain and pain over her right shoulder. She had a history of gastric ulcer which had been treated previously with medication, but on questioning, she admitted that she had been so busy recently that she had forgotten to refill her prescription and had not taken her medication in some time. As a result of the history and physical findings, the physician suspected that she was suffering from a perforated gastric ulcer. Gastroscopy was performed which confirmed the diagnosis. When the surgeon examined the patient’s stomach during the surgery, she found a small perforation on the posterior aspect of the body of the stomach near the lesser curvature. The perforation was repaired and, in addition, a vagotomy was performed. During the vagotomy, the surgeon found it necessary to cut the left gastric artery and ligate it. Which of the following statement pertaining to the above case is incorrect?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Collateral Circulation from Branches of Superior Mesenteric Artery will compensate Occlusion of Left Gastric Artery

choices.text: Permanent dilation of alveoli and loss of elastic recoil
Accumulation of fluid within the alveoli
Entry of air into the pleural space

questions.text: A 54-year-old man who had smoked two packs of cigarettes per day for 20 years complains of the acute onset of shortness of breath, and severe chest pain with respiratory movement. Physical examination reveals a barrel chest consistent with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. There are decreased breath sounds on the right side. When the physician taps on the right chest (percussion), there is a hyperresonant (unusually hollow) sound.  What is the anatomical disorder?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Entry of air into the pleural space

questions.text: All the following structures drain into the marked structure except:
Which nerve out the labelling below is responsible for cremasteric reflex?
Which zone of the prostate is predominantly involved in BPH?

A 65-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain that began about 6 hours ago. She also complains of vague pelvic pain over the last few months, but says her pain has never been this severe. Her temperature is 38.4⁰C (101 ⁰F), blood pressure is 141/90 mmHg, pulse is 92/min, and respirations are 18/min. Physical examination shows a moderately distended abdomen. There is a tender bulge below the inguinal ligament, lateral to the pubic tubercle. The overlying skin is erythematous. Which of the following structures is most likely immediately lateral to the bulge?

choices.text: Both A and R are correct, and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are correct, and R is not the correct explanation of A
A is correct, but R is wrong
Both A and R are wrong

questions.text:
Assertion: External haemorrhoids are extremely painful while internal haemorrhoids are painless

Reason:  Area above the dentate line receives somatic nerve supply while area below dentate line receives autonomic nerve supply
questions.solution: Ans. C) A is correct, but R is wrong

choices.text: Shifted upward and to the left, indicating increased contractility and decreased preload.
Shifted downward and to the left, indicating decreased contractility and decreased preload.
Shifted upward and to the right, indicating increased contractility and increased preload.
Shifted downward and to the right, indicating decreased contractility and increased preload.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman with a history of chronic anxiety disorder presents to the clinic complaining of occasional palpitations and shortness of breath. Her ECG and echocardiogram are normal, but her symptoms are suggestive of heightened sympathetic activity. Considering the impact of sympathetic stimulation on cardiac muscle, how would you expect the length-tension curve of her myocardium to change?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Shifted upward and to the left, indicating increased contractility and decreased preload.

questions.text: While analyzing the impact of acute blood loss on cardiac function by interpreting changes in the Frank-Starling curves. Understanding how various clinical interventions or pathophysiological states affect stroke volume is vital. Given the patient's condition of mild hemorrhage and the associated compensatory mechanisms, to which point will the stroke volume shift from point X on the graph?

In an advanced cardiology training session, fellows are interpreting ejection fraction (EF) from a left ventricular pressure-volume loop. The ejection fraction is a crucial measure of ventricular efficiency and cardiac function. Based on the pressure-volume loop provided, calculate the ejection fraction and choose the correct answer from the options below.

In a complex cardiology case study session, participants are tasked with determining the cardiac index of a patient undergoing evaluation for potential heart failure. The patient's stroke volume is recorded at 70 mL/beat, and their heart rate is 80 beats/min, with a body surface area (BSA) of 2.0 m². To calculate the cardiac index, which of the following values is correct based on the provided data?

In a cardiology research seminar, fellows are analyzing the changes in pressure-volume loops and their implications for various cardiac conditions. A key concept being discussed is the leftward shift of the pressure-volume loop and its clinical significance. Based on the characteristics of different cardiac pathologies, which condition is typically associated with a leftward shift in the pressure-volume loop?

choices.text: Increased Anatomical Dead Space, Decreased Alveolar Dead Space
Decreased Anatomical Dead Space, Increased Alveolar Dead Space
Increased both Anatomical and Alveolar Dead Space
Decreased both Anatomical and Alveolar Dead Space

questions.text: A 63-year-old male on ventilator support with a long history of smoking and chronic bronchitis is undergoing evaluation for respiratory difficulties. His spirometry shows a significant reduction in forced expiratory volume, and a CT scan reveals emphysematous changes in the lungs. In this scenario, what would be the expected changes in both anatomical and alveolar dead space?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Increased both Anatomical and Alveolar Dead Space.

choices.text: Intra-Pleural Pressure is always Greater than Intra-Pulmonary Pressure (IPP) during Inspiration
Trans-Pulmonary Pressure (TPP) is the difference between Intra-Pleural Pressure (ITP) and Intra-Pulmonary Pressure
Intra-Pulmonary Pressure (IPP) is always higher than Atmospheric Pressure
Trans-Respiratory pressure is the difference between Intra-Pleural Pressure (ITP) and Trans-Pulmonary Pressure (TPP)

questions.text: During a Medical Simulation Exercise, a patient present with Respiratory Distress. The Medical Team is discussing the various pressures involved in the Respiratory System. Which of the following statements accurately describes the relationship between the Different Pressures in the Pulmonary Circulation for this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Trans-Pulmonary Pressure (TPP) is the difference between Intra-Pleural Pressure (ITP) and Intra-Pulmonary Pressure

questions.text: What will be the Oxygen carrying capacity of an 18-year-old patient with hemoglobin of 14 gm/dL?
Which of the following lung pathologies result in increased dynamic compliance but decreased static compliance?

An elderly patient presents with altered sensorium, vomiting and dehydration. His breathing was deep and laboured.  His ABG analysis revealed an anion gap of 25 mOsmol/kg. which of the following can be ruled out based on given scenario?

choices.text: E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase, E2: Dihydrolipoyl transacetylase
E1: Pyruvate Decarboxylase, E2: Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase
E1: Pyruvate carboxylase, E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase
E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase, E2: Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase

questions.text: This multienzyme complex converts Pyruvate to Acetyl CoA. Identify E1 and E2.
questions.solution: Ans. A) E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase, E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase

questions.text: Enzyme active in low insulin:glucagon ratio is:

A 54-year-old male presents with weakness, fatigue, shortness of breath and dizziness. Hb was found to be 6.4 g/dl. RBC shows low lactate production. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely in this patient?
Which of the following compounds does not give a positive reaction in the test shown below?

A seven-month-old female infant, a product of a consanguineous marriage, was admitted for progressive abdominal distention, vomiting, and lethargy for four months. There was no history of seizure or recurrent infections. Her development was slightly delayed. There was a family history of the death of a cousin during infancy due to liver disease. On physical examination, the lethargic infant had a rounded doll's face, fatty cheeks, and a protuberant abdomen; weight below the tenth percentile; and length below the fifth. Systemic examination was unremarkable except for a massive and firm hepatomegaly (liver span was 14 centimeter). The spleen and kidneys were not palpable. Apart from the low blood glucose level, blood chemistry revealed high lactic acid level, hyperlipidemia, hyperuricemia, mild elevation in liver enzymes, normal creatine kinase levels, and arterial blood gases revealed high anion gap metabolic acidosis. What is the likely diagnosis?
To which of the following omega groups does the fatty acid with the nomenclature C 18:2; 9,12 belong to?

choices.text: Medium chain acyl CoA DH deficiency

questions.text: Identify the metabolic error in the syndrome characterised by the following findings.
questions.solution: Ans. C) Phytanic acid oxidase deficiency

choices.text: Lp A is associated with apoA1
Lp B is also known as “good cholesterol”
Lp C is obtained from dietary sources

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about the lipoproteins shown in the image below?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Lp A is associated with apoA1

questions.text: Most common metabolite of progesterone excreted in urine:
Krabbe’s disease or globoid cell leukodystrophy is a fatal, degenerative disorder affecting myelin sheath. Lipid accumulating in Krabbe’s disease is:
